rev.diff:
Line 143: Line 143:
''Al Jazeera'' reported an ''[[Associated Press]]'' claim that an elite counterterrorism force that had been deployed at strategic points around [[Cairo]], and that Egypt's interior ministry was warning of "decisive measures". The secretary-general of the ruling National Democratic Party, [[Safwat Sherif]], held a press conference stating, "We hope that tomorrow's Friday prayers and its rituals happen in a quiet way that upholds the value of such rituals ... and that no one jeopardises the safety of citizens or subjects them to something they do not want."<ref name="aljazeera2">{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/201112810059478272.html |title=Fresh Protests Erupt in Egypt |work=[[Al Jazeera English]] |date=28 January 2011 |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref>
''Al Jazeera'' reported an ''[[Associated Press]]'' claim that an elite counterterrorism force that had been deployed at strategic points around [[Cairo]], and that Egypt's interior ministry was warning of "decisive measures". The secretary-general of the ruling National Democratic Party, [[Safwat Sherif]], held a press conference stating, "We hope that tomorrow's Friday prayers and its rituals happen in a quiet way that upholds the value of such rituals ... and that no one jeopardises the safety of citizens or subjects them to something they do not want."<ref name="aljazeera2">{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/201112810059478272.html |title=Fresh Protests Erupt in Egypt |work=[[Al Jazeera English]] |date=28 January 2011 |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref>
â
Amid reports of looting of government buildings, concerns were raised about the safety of the antiquities of the famous [[Egyptian Museum]], near the epicenter of the protests in Cairo. Egyptian state TV announced in the evening that army commandos had secured the museum.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Egypt Army Secures Museum with Pharaonic Treasures|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2011/01/28/arts-us-egypt-museum-idUKTRE70R7K820110128|work=[[Reuters]]|date=28 January 2011|accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref> Protesters joined soldiers in protecting the [[Egyptian Museum]], situated beside the burning ruling party headquarters.<ref name="AlJazeera29th1pm">Breaking News. ''[[Al Jazeera English]]''. 29 November 1:00 Egypt time</ref> Looters managed to enter during the night from the roof to damage a number of small artifacts, and it was initially reported that they had ripped the heads off two mummies, but subsequent reports claimed that Egypt's top archaeologist had mistaken skulls from other skeletons, and that the mummies were intact.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Looters Destroy Mummies in Egyptian Museum|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2011/01/29/us-egypt-museum-idUKTRE70S1YU20110129|work=[[Reuters]]|date=29 January 2011|accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Torchia, Christopher|title=AP Interview: Egypt Declares Treasures Safe|url=http://hosted.ap.org/dynamic/stories/M/ML_EGYPT_PROTEST_ANTIQUITIES?SITE=TNKNN&SECTION=HOME&TEMPLATE=DEFAULT|publisher=''[[Associated Press]]'' (via ''[[Knoxville News Sentinel]]'')|date=1 February 2011|accessdate=4 February 2011}}</ref>
+
Amid reports of looting of government buildings, concerns were raised about the safety of the antiquities of the famous [[Egyptian Museum]], near the epicenter of the protests in Cairo. Egyptian state TV announced in the evening that army commandos had secured the museum.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Egypt Army Secures Museum with Pharaonic Treasures|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2011/01/28/arts-us-egypt-museum-idUKTRE70R7K820110128|work=[[Reuters]]|date=28 January 2011|accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref> Protesters joined soldiers in protecting the [[Egyptian Museum]], situated beside the burning ruling party headquarters.<ref name="AlJazeera29th1pm">{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/01/29/live-blog-291-egypt-protests |title=Live Blog Jan 29 – Egypt Protests |work=[[Al Jazeera]] |date= |accessdate=4 January 2011}}</ref> Looters managed to enter during the night from the roof to damage a number of small artifacts, and it was initially reported that they had ripped the heads off two mummies, but subsequent reports claimed that Egypt's top archaeologist had mistaken skulls from other skeletons, and that the mummies were intact.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Looters Destroy Mummies in Egyptian Museum|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2011/01/29/us-egypt-museum-idUKTRE70S1YU20110129|work=[[Reuters]]|date=29 January 2011|accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Torchia, Christopher|title=AP Interview: Egypt Declares Treasures Safe|url=http://hosted.ap.org/dynamic/stories/M/ML_EGYPT_PROTEST_ANTIQUITIES?SITE=TNKNN&SECTION=HOME&TEMPLATE=DEFAULT|publisher=''[[Associated Press]]'' (via ''[[Knoxville News Sentinel]]'')|date=1 February 2011|accessdate=4 February 2011}}</ref>
The detention of ElBaradei prompted the U.S. to review its $1.5 billion aid package for Egypt; he was later released.<ref name="G01"/> The day's defiance was summed up by the plethora of [[Tunisia]]n national flags and anti-Mubarak [[graffiti]] that the protesters had created in the [[Greater Cairo]] region, Alexandria, Beni Suef, Mansoura and Manufiya.<ref name="chron1"/> Meanwhile, the [[Muslim Brotherhood]] said that twenty members of the banned group had been detained overnight, including Essam El-Erian, its main spokesman, and Mohammed Moursi, one of the its leaders.<ref name="aljazeera2"/>
The detention of ElBaradei prompted the U.S. to review its $1.5 billion aid package for Egypt; he was later released.<ref name="G01"/> The day's defiance was summed up by the plethora of [[Tunisia]]n national flags and anti-Mubarak [[graffiti]] that the protesters had created in the [[Greater Cairo]] region, Alexandria, Beni Suef, Mansoura and Manufiya.<ref name="chron1"/> Meanwhile, the [[Muslim Brotherhood]] said that twenty members of the banned group had been detained overnight, including Essam El-Erian, its main spokesman, and Mohammed Moursi, one of the its leaders.<ref name="aljazeera2"/>
